title: Terrifying that this is nonfiction
content: Were it not for the underlying disregard for their race and therefore worth as human beings, this story is very much the age old story about human greed. But thanks to the efforts of federal law enforcement as came to be embodied with the founding of the FBI, the perpetrators, largely Whites but not exclusively, were caught and prosecuted. It is how the author weaves together the story to solve the mystery and in the process ties in side stories about the Indian plight in America and how the Osage by virtually total accident came to reside in one of the richest oil reserves in the country and as a consequence became for a time, the richest Americans because of royalties from the mineral rights, that provides for compelling reading.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: A positive aspect of the writing is that while the author engages in a handful of side stories to add perspective, they are efficient and accretive to the story, not mini books in themselves that become tedious distractions to the story that characterize too many works of non-fiction. When the main story ended about three quarters through and the author embarked on an epilogue I began to fear his story discipline had broken down. But as it happened the author used the epilogue to tie together loose ends of the story post solving of the murders in the mid 1920s. Very satisfying.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I rarely read nonfiction books, and I have never read this author's work, but I am glad that I took the time to read this book before I see the movie later this month. The author is very thorough in his research and very detailed in his writing. The story was completely unknown to me. The Osage tribe of Native Americans earned a lot of money from the oil found on their reservation and started out quite rich. However, lawbreaking citizens managed to steal much of the money from the tribe members. When some tribe members ended up dead, the federal government got involved. At this time there was no national police, so newly formed groups investigated, leading to the formation of the FBI. I enjoyed reading this author's work, and will try some of his other work.

title: Very readable nonfiction book
content: This was an exciting page-turning crime investigation book.  The pace is a bit slow at first, but when the gruesome murders accumulate (and suspicious cover-ups from local officials begin), it grips the reader.  I also enjoyed the history of this non-fiction work as it showcases the FBI's emergence, the heroic work of Tom White (who lived to 91 years after leading the FBI investigation and nearly losing his life as a prison warden), and the Reign of Terror which brought trauma to the Osage Indians in the early 20th century.  It is awful that suspicions still persist for Osage Indians living in Oklahoma today.

title: A Hauntingly Devastating True Murder Mystery
content: Here's my honest opinion. Some peope will give this a 5-star review simply because it's a very compelling story, which it is. I went into it expecting more entertainment, but this reads very similar to a crime documentary that you'd watch on TV. There are twists and turns, but it's mostly just the facts being put forward. This is a historical account that we should have already known, but has been hidden from us. This is one of the most important events in native American history, yet I had never heard of the Osage nation until I read this. It is important, shocking, and necessary history that everyone should read. Just don't do it just because you heard the movie was good. The events are wrapped up by 60%. Sentences are passed, time is served, everyone eventually dies. I'd like some of my money back for the last 40%.

title: The story no one knows about; after reading you will know why!
content: This Book was suggested to me by Amazon. It happen to hit upon a subject in which I am trying to learn more about, The Osage Indian. I live in a part of Arkansas which was once part of the Great Osage Nation. We still occasionally find Indian artifacts which may or may not have been made by the Osage. I have tried reading more about them but most of what I had learned is limited to they once lived here. In the early 1800's the government moved them to Kansas and like all other Native Americans were placed on a reservation. Now comes this fantastic book by David Grann. Having received this book with no prior knowledge one only gambles. However, I couldn't put it down and I can't stop thinking about it. The author in my opinion told the story with a great deal of empathy for the Osage People and with a great deal of respect in reference to Tom White, former Texas lawman to FBI agent  for purposes of this story. The story takes place in the early 1920's with a view of an Osage Nation through great leadership had chosen to purchase land in Oklahoma. The land was suggested to be so poor and worthless that no white man would want it. How wrong could they have been but how smart they were in the purchase. With the help of John Palmer an native american lawyer I have read about before, they were able to purchase the land thus having a deed and no longer dependent on government granted reservation land. Then Oil is discovered and of course the white man comes knocking on the door in attempt to gain access to the black gold below the surface. John Palmer however had gone a step further and as the author suggests was able to sneak in language whereby the tribe withheld all mineral rights. Clearly, this stumped all land grabbers who had made an art of obtaining valuable tribal land from various tribes throughout history. But wait, the story now begins because others with no particular thought as to the Osage people even being human, make their land grab and this is the story so artfully told by Mr. Grann. I cannot recommend this book enough. Here is a tribe that has done everything legally right but yet they were disappearing. Most people knew what was going on and why, but these people were also the culprits which made it almost impossible for the FBI to trust any information they obtained. J. Edgar Hoover was new in his job at this time and he was looking for just the right cases to help him argue for a National Police. This was one of the first cases that helped move them to the very respected FBI.  Oddly the term "most people" referenced above, still fits because as the story develops, the reader is shocked by the cruelty and total disregard for human life over the almighty dollar and these atrocities were being orchestrated by the very people who were chosen to look out for them. Go get it read it and enjoy!!!!  I recently watched Mr. Grann being interviewed on television. There is discussion he stated, where big name movie directors, producers, et cetera are wanting to make a movie out of this book. Well, it will be interesting to see, but rest assured, no movie will be as good as this book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2017

title: Verified Purchase
content: David Grann's "Killers of the Flower Moon" is an eye-opening look into an episode of American history of which I had never heard. In the early 20th Century, one of the many and ever-changing treaties between the US Government and Native Americans had assigned a major portion of Oklahoma to the Osage Indian tribe.  Surprisingly, it turned out to be extremely oil rich, and members of the tribe became millionaires.  They lived in mansions and had servants. Still, they suffered many indignities, such as having a "guardian" (usually a Caucasian) assigned to handle their business affairs, as native Americans were not deemed competent to handle their own money. One thing that surprised me was that there were no laws prohibiting interracial marriages among Caucasians and native Americans.  The reason I didn't expect such unions would be legal was knowing that interracial marriages among whites and blacks were not allowed until a Supreme Court case in the 1967.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021

title: A must read for every American citizen who wants to know the truth about our history!
content: In the 1920s, a series of mysterious deaths began to occur among the Osage.  While some deaths resembled natural causes, they were unexplained and could have been the result of poisoning. Some were obviously murders, by gunshot wounds or stabbing. Multiple family members of Mollie Burkhart were among the victims. In those days, forensics as we know it today did not exist.  Autopsies were crude, and crime scenes were not preserved. When Mollie's sister was shot, the men who performed the autopsy could not find the bullet in her head, even though there was no exit wound. Law enforcement was extremely limited.  Citizens had to turn to private investigators for answers.  Material witnesses seemed to disappear or clam up.  A man went to Washington DC to seek help from federal authorities, but was ambushed and killed upon his arrival in the capitol city.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Eventually, help did come from DC, from the organization that preceded and evolved into the FBI.  Because of the non cooperation and unreliability of witnesses, the feds resorted to undercover work that took years.  The old saying that "truth is stranger than fiction," certainly applies to this case.  I was absolutely floored by who was really behind the killings and how the convoluted motive was supposed to work.  Though you might be tempted to Google it before the end - don't.  Reading it as Grann reveals it makes it more stunning. No wonder this was one of the top-selling nonfiction books in 2017.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2024
